box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 125px; margin-left: 751px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 125px; margin-left: 1001px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 125px; margin-left: 1251px;

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 182px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 455px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font: Spoofing violates authenticity.
Spoofing refers to the act of posing as someone else (i.e. spoofing a user) or claiming a false identity (i.e. spoofing a process).
One user spoofs the identify of another user by brute-forcing username/password credentials.
You would typically mitigate these risks with proper authentication.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 182px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 255px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 505px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font:
Tampering violates integrity.
Tampering refers to malicious modification of data or processes. Tampering may occur on data in transit, on data at rest, or on processes.
Examples:
A user performs bit-flipping attacks on data in transit.
A user modifies data at rest/on disk.
A user performs injection attacks on the application.
Proper validation of users' inputs and proper encoding of outputs.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 192px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 505px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 435px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font:
Repudiation violates non-repudiability.
Repudiation refers to the ability of denying that an action or an event has occurred.
Examples:
A user denies performing a destructive action (e.g. deleting all records from a database).
Mitigation:
You would typically mitigate these risks with proper audit logging.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 182px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 755px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 565px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font: Information disclosure violates confidentiality.

font.span: Information Disclosure refers to data leaks or data breaches. This could occur on data in transit, data at rest, or even to a process.

p.font: A user is able to eavesdrop, sniff, or read traffic in clear-text.
A user is able to read data on disk in clear-text.
A user attacks an application protected by TLS but is able to steal x.509 (SSL/TLS certificate) decryption keys and other sensitive information. Yes, this happened.
A user is able to read sensitive data in a database.
Implementing encryption.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 172px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 1005px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 515px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font: Denial of service violates availability.
Denial of Service refers to causing a service or a network resource to be unavailable to its intended users.
A user performs SYN flood attack.
The storage (i.e. disk, drive) becomes too full.
Mitigating this class of security risks is tricky because solutions are highly dependent on a lot of factors.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 182px; height: 1px; padding-top: 255px; margin-left: 1255px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 525px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Merriweather Sans"; color: rgb(255, 255, 255); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font: Elevation of privilege violates authorization.
Elevation of Privileges refers to gaining access that one should not have.

A user takes advantage of a Buffer Overflow to gain root-level privileges on a system.
Mitigation:
Proper authorization mechanism (e.g. role-based access control).
Generally practicing least privilege principle, like running your web server as a non-root user.

a.text: Text is not SVG - cannot display
